More than half of a year has passed since this struggle entered its fiercest phase. What a cataract of calamity has descended upon us since then. The trust of the people in Washington and Los Angeles suppressed; their voices silenced beneath bluster; their free institutions mocked. Our allies in truth and democracy harried and betrayed. Entire communities of our nation, gutted and abandoned, their hopes of fraternity as brutally torn as any rampart in war.
Yet here in Chicago, we stand—undaunted, unbroken, resolute. 

If in January, one had told us that, after such disaster and shock, we should stand upright in September, masters of our own resolve, firm in the conviction of ultimate triumph, few would have credited it. Yet so it is. Where others faltered, Chicago has not wavered. We are stronger today—stronger in spirit, stronger in unity, stronger in the faith that justice shall prevail—than ever we have been before.

The Trump faction believed that the air of confusion, the tempest of words, could cow us—that by unbridled assault upon truth, they could drive us to submission. Yet the good men and women of Chicago have risen nobly, as never before. They have labored unceasingly, they have restored their strength, they have bristled their city against tyranny from within or from without. Chicago today is a fortress for Democrat, a beacon of hope, a sentinel of justice.

It is quite plain that Mr. Trump could not admit defeat in his assault upon the institutions of American democracy without sustaining the most serious injury. If, after all his vainglorious boastings, his dire threats, and the lurid accounts so loudly trumpeted across the nation of the triumphs he claims to have inflicted—of the vast numbers of crimes he alleges were committed, of the multitudes he insists have risen to his cause, and of the pitiful weakness of our civic order—if, after all these extravagant tales of Washington and Los Angeles laid low, their citizens panic-stricken and despairing of their government, if, after such a torrent of words, his whole offensive should, in the end, be forced to dwindle and fade into nothingness, the gentleman’s reputation for veracity, slender though it already is, would suffer the most grievous discredit. 

We may be sure, therefore, that he will persist as long as strength and circumstance allow, and as long as the manifold preoccupations of his legal entanglements with Epstein are in need of diversion from public purview and discourse.

On the other hand, the Patriotic spirit of free men and women has increased in vigour. Our capacity for endurance is already shown to exceed theirs. Each falsehood, once unmasked, becomes a weapon against him. Each scheme revealed serves not his cause, but ours.

And so I say this: The gratitude of every home in Chicago, of every family that lifts its head in freedom, of every heart across this nation that esteems liberty above servitude, goes forth to those few champions of truth and courage, who against overwhelming odds, in the heat of this mighty trial, turn the tide by their devotion.

Never, in the field of public struggle, was so much owed by so many to so few.

Statement from Congressman Jonathan Jackson on the Passing of Former President Jimmy Carter

Today, we grieve the passing of Former President Jimmy Carter, a leader of unparalleled integrity and compassion who devoted his life to the pursuit of justice, equality, and peace. At 100 years old, he leaves behind a legacy that profoundly shaped our nation and the world.

President Carter’s dedication to civil rights was evident in his actions both before and during his presidency. As Governor of Georgia, he called for an end to segregation and publicly declared that the time for racial discrimination had passed. His bold leadership in the South during a time of immense tension sent a powerful message of inclusion and progress.

As president, Jimmy Carter demonstrated a deep commitment to addressing systemic inequalities affecting Black communities. His administration significantly increased federal appointments of African Americans to high-ranking positions, creating opportunities for representation in spaces of power. He also expanded funding for historically Black colleges and universities, understanding that education is a cornerstone of opportunity.

President Carter worked closely with my father, Reverend Jesse Jackson, to empower marginalized communities and advance the cause of economic justice. Their collaboration helped secure greater access to federal resources for minority-owned businesses, particularly through the Minority Business Development Agency, which Carter strengthened during his presidency. Together, they emphasized the importance of uplifting underserved communities through economic inclusion, employment opportunities, and community investment.

Beyond his presidency, President Carter continued to work alongside civil rights leaders like my father. He joined efforts to mediate racial and economic disparities, offering his wisdom and influence to bring people together in pursuit of equality. His efforts through the Carter Center tackled issues like voter suppression, housing insecurity, and global poverty, which disproportionately affect communities of color. His hands-on involvement with Habitat for Humanity built not just homes, but hope, for families striving for a better future.

President Carter’s moral leadership and tangible actions remind us that true progress requires not just words but deeds. He transformed the presidency into a platform for service and ensured that the fight for civil rights remained central to the American story.

On behalf of the constituents of Illinois’ 1st District, I extend my heartfelt condolences to the Carter family and to all those mourning this extraordinary man. May we honor his legacy by continuing his work to build a world where justice, dignity, and opportunity are within reach for all.

Rest in peace, President Carter. Your life’s work will forever inspire us.

Congressman Jonathan L. Jackson Decries Acquittal of Daniel Penny in Jordan Neely’s Death

“Is this who we are? Is this the new normal?” Congressman Jackson Urges Action to Restore the Sanctity of Life and Justice for Black Lives

Washington, D.C. — Congressman Jonathan L. Jackson issued a powerful statement today in response to the acquittal of Daniel Penny, who faced charges related to the death of Jordan Neely, a young Black man experiencing a mental health crisis on a New York City subway.

“The outcome of this trial forces us to confront troubling questions about the society we are becoming. Is this who we are? Are we willing to accept a new normal where vigilantes feel entitled to take justice into their own hands, especially when it comes to Black lives?

Jordan Neely’s story is a heartbreaking reminder of the challenges faced by individuals living with mental health struggles. He deserved compassion, care, and assistance—not a violent end. The decision to acquit Daniel Penny sends a dangerous signal: that some lives, particularly Black lives, can be devalued without consequence.

This verdict mirrors systemic disparities we’ve seen time and again. Consider how frequently Black men are subjected to harsh penalties for less severe actions. Cases like Albert Wilson and Kalief Browder underscore the glaring inequities in our justice system. Meanwhile, individuals like Penny, who take lethal action, are absolved. We must ask ourselves how we reconcile these outcomes with our claims of justice and equality.”
“America has always been a nation that wrestles with its conscience. Today, I urge us all to rise above fear and indifference, to embrace our better angels, and to reaffirm the value of every human life.

The killing of Jordan Neely should never have happened. It speaks to a failure on many levels: a failure of compassion, a failure of public systems to provide adequate mental health support, and a failure of the justice system to ensure accountability.

No one struggling with a mental health crisis should face violence instead of help. No Black life should be so easily disregarded. As a nation, we must reckon with this and commit to charting a different course.”

“This tragic case highlights urgent areas for action. As members of Congress, it is our responsibility to address the underlying issues that allow these injustices to persist.
1. Increase Oversight on the Use of Force:
Pass legislation that establishes      stricter standards for holding individuals accountable when they use      lethal force outside the boundaries of the law.
2. Improve Mental Health Support Systems:
Expand funding for crisis      intervention programs and mental health resources, particularly for      underserved communities.

Prioritize the passage of the Mental      Health Equity Act, which aims to address mental health disparities in      communities of color.

3. Curtail Vigilantism:
Strengthen federal penalties for      individuals who engage in extrajudicial violence, ensuring that no one      takes the law into their own hands without consequences.

4. Reform the Justice System:
Support legislation like the George      Floyd Justice in Policing Act to address racial bias and inequity in      the legal process.

5. Promote Community-Based Solutions:
Increase investments in programs      that provide non-violent responses to mental health crises, including      mobile crisis response units and peer support networks.”

6. Address Veterans’ Mental Health Needs:
Adding complexity to this tragedy is Daniel Penny’s status as a military veteran. Veterans are among our nation’s most respected citizens, yet too often they face severe challenges, including mental health crises that go unaddressed. Congress must take proactive steps to ensure that veterans receive comprehensive mental health support. It is imperative to provide the necessary resources to prevent any veteran from contributing to or being caught in such devastating situations. The tragic loss of Jordan Neely is a reminder of Congress's responsibility to protect its citizens, invest in mental health services, and reform judicial inequities.

To this end, legislators like Congressmen David Trone and Ro Khanna have sponsored critical measures to address mental health needs, including:

The Occupational Therapy Mental      Health Parity Act, which enhances access to occupational therapy for mental health      under Medicare, ensuring veterans and others can access holistic,      life-improving services.
H.R. 2067, the Medication Access and      Training Expansion (MATE) Act, designed to improve training for      treating substance use disorders, which are closely tied to mental health      issues.

These legislative efforts emphasize the need for targeted support systems for veterans, addressing underlying issues such as PTSD, anxiety, and societal reintegration challenges.

Advocate for national standards      in crisis response, ensuring trained professionals—not civilians—intervene      in mental health emergencies.

Expand funding for community      mental health programs and veterans' mental health services to prevent      tragedies like this.

Congress must increase funding      for veterans’ mental health services through the Department of Veterans      Affairs (VA), including therapy, counseling, and crisis intervention.

Support legislation that expands      training for veterans transitioning to civilian life, focusing on      de-escalation and understanding mental health crises in the community.

By addressing veterans’ mental health needs comprehensively, we can ensure that our heroes receive the care they deserve while also helping to prevent situations where unresolved trauma may lead to tragedy.

“The acquittal of Daniel Penny is not just a failure of the courts—it is a failure of our collective humanity. This moment calls on all of us to reflect and act. Allowing tragedies like this to become the norm is unacceptable.
The time has come to renew our commitment to protecting the vulnerable, ensuring justice for the marginalized, and reaffirming the inherent dignity of every person.
Jordan Neely’s life mattered. Black lives matter. And as a nation, we must do better to honor that truth.”

Today, we remember #DikembeMutombo, a giant both on and off the basketball court.

Born on June 25, 1966, in Kinshasa, #Zaire, Mutombo was one of ten children. His father, an educator, ensured that his children had access to good schools. Dikembe’s early dreams were of becoming a doctor, and he eventually mastered nine languages, including French, English, Spanish, Portuguese, and five Central African dialects.

His journey from #Kinshasa to the NBA is a testament to his determination and resilience.  Mutombo was a four-time NBA Defensive Player of the Year and an eight-time All-Star. His iconic finger wag and relentless defense made him a household name, but it was his humanitarian efforts that truly defined his legacy.

He dedicated his life to improving health and education in his native Democratic Republic of #Congo. Through the Dikembe Mutombo Foundation, he built the Biamba Marie Mutombo Hospital, providing critical healthcare services to thousands. His initiatives included free cervical and breast cancer screenings, knee and cataract surgeries.

As a UNICEF global ambassador and a tireless advocate, Dikembe’s impact was felt worldwide. His work with the NBA Cares program and various international relief agencies showcased his unwavering commitment to making the world a better place.

Congressman Jonathan L. Jackson calls for the Censure of Rep. Clay Higgins after Racist remarks against Haitians

Louisiana and Haiti have a shared history. Today, we should be celebrating and reflecting upon the rich and intertwined heritage of these connected cultures. These two regions, though separated by the Gulf of Mexico, share a bond that has profoundly shaped their cultures, economies, and identities.

In 1791, enslaved Africans in Haiti rose against their oppressors, leading to the first successful slave rebellion in history. This revolution culminated in Haiti becoming the first independent Black republic in 1804.
The impact of this Revolution extended far beyond the island’s shores. France, weakened by the loss of its most profitable colony sold the vast Louisiana Territory to the United States in 1803. This acquisition doubled the size of America and opened up the continent for westward expansion. There would be no America as we know it, without Haiti.

The connections between Haiti and Louisiana are deeply cultural. Following the Revolution, many refugees, including free people of color, planters, and enslaved individuals, fled to Louisiana, particularly New Orleans. They brought with them their customs, cuisine, music, and religious practices, which have since become integral to the cultural fabric of Louisiana. The word “Gumbo” itself comes from the West African word “ki ngombo,” which translates to okra.

The influence of Haitian culture is evident in the vibrant Creole cuisine, the rhythms of jazz, and the spiritual practices of Voodoo. The architecture of the French Quarter bears the mark of this shared heritage and Creole languages reflect their common roots in French colonialism and African heritage.

This shared history is what makes the words of Louisiana Congressman Clay Higgins all the more disgusting, abhorrent, and despicable. Congressman Higgins posted on his official account:

"LOL, These Haitians are wild. Eating pets, vudu, nastiest country in the western hemisphere, cults, slapstick gangsters... but damned if they don’t feel all sophisticated now, filing charges against our President and VP, All these thugs better get their mind right and their ass out of our country before January 20th”

These comments represent a new low even for Extreme MAGA Republicans. Higgins, a former policeman and sheriff's deputy in St. Landry Parish was disciplined by his commanding officer in Opelousas after he struck a handcuffed Black man and then lied about it amid an internal probe. He has bragged about voting for and supporting Klansman David Duke. In 2020, when protesters marched to bring justice for Breonna Taylor he used his official House account to post:

“If this shows up, we’ll consider the armed presence a real threat,” "I'd drop any 10 of you where you stand," "Nothing personal. We just eliminate the threat. We don't care what color you are. We don't care if you're left or right. if you show up like this, if We recognize a threat...you won't walk away."

What’s worse, is not the sentiments of Mr. Higgins but the response from his fellow Republicans. As Martin Luther King, Jr. once said “History will have to record that the greatest tragedy of this period of social transition was not the strident clamor of the bad people, but the appalling silence of the good people.” Mr. Higgins holds deep-seated fears and hatred of people who do not look like him. But the silence of Republican leadership has been so much more deafening and hurtful.

I call on Speaker of the House Johnson and the leaders of the Republican Party to join us in condemning Congressman Higgins; additionally, I join my colleagues in the Congressional Black Caucus in calling for the censure of the Member. His statements violate the House Rules regarding the conduct of a member and put the lives of millions of Haitians, other immigrants, and people of color in danger.

Speaker Johnson has said that Mr. Higgins has prayed on the issues and has atoned for his statement saying “I’m sure he probably regrets some of the language he used. But you know, we move forward. We believe in redemption around here.” However, Mr. Higgins has shown no such remorse saying:

· “It’s all true!”
· “I can put up another controversial post tomorrow if you want me to. I mean, we do have freedom of speech. I’ll say what I want.”
· “It’s not a big deal to me. It’s like something stuck to the bottom of my boot. Just scrape it off and move on with my life.”

Mr. Higgins and his Project 2025, Extreme MAGA Republican allies are intent on doubling down and tripling down of hateful rhetoric and division. For this reason, the House of Representatives must act with one voice and vote to censure Representative Higgins.
